Title: the 43 peculiarity

Scene: The cafeteria. Sheldon is drawing on a napkin.
A corridor in the basement. Sheldon takes out a key, unlocks a door and enters.
The room in the basement. Sheldon enters, takes out a box, takes a beanbag from the box, then starts playing keepie-uppie,
Raj: What are you drawing over there?
He probably just goes to the bathroom.
It’s sad that you know that.
Twenty minutes a day, completely unaccounted for.
Ooh, this is exciting. Like one of my classic murder mystery dinner parties.
It was tapenade and you guys suck.
Are you sure? They turn off the lights, and it’s like a cute little laser show that poops all over the place.
We just told you.
I don’t know, I’m torn. I want to know where he’s going, but now I kind of want to play with the bunny.
Boy, what I wouldn’t give to get her out of those pants and into something a little more stylish.
I think it’s an old storage room.
Well, he’s not doing twenty-minute abs, because if he were, he would have way better abs. Can you hear anything?
I’m listening.
I can’t do anything right for you, can I?
He is kind of a weirdo. Maybe he’s got Leonard Nimoy chained up in there. Or Bill Gates. Or Stephen Hawking.
Howard, please, you can’t treat the man differently just because he’s disabled. That’s not okay.
Look at us, sneaking around in the middle of the night like a couple of cat burglars.
I don’t want to be a ninja, I want to be a cat burglar.
No, we both have to be the same thing. Okay, we’re ninjas.
But next time, we’ll be cat burglars.
Are you sure?
When did you learn how to pick locks?
How did that work out?
Hold on, hold on.
Sheldon is a very smart man, and he obviously wants to keep this a secret.
What if it’s booby-trapped?
Great, what’s your pl… (Howard pushes him inside)
Yeah. Huh. Forty-three? What the hell does that mean?
Maybe. It’s a prime number. Encryption systems are built on prime numbers.
He’s always been very cagey about what he puts in his egg salad to make it so tasty.
Really? Well, oh, okay, one mystery solved.
Come on, we’re smart guys. We can figure this out.
It’s the atomic number for technetium.
Do you think he’s building a bomb?
Ooh, this could be something. forty-three is the number of calories in half a cup of fat-free yoghurt.
I’m sorry. We can’t all eat whatever we want and still stay thin. Wait, in the Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, isn’t forty-three the answer to the question of life, the universe,and everything?
Hey, hey. Feelings.
Yeah, me, too. We’ve got more important things to do. Who cares what stupid forty-three means?
Let’s go home. You want to get something to eat?
What the balls is forty-three?
That’s good quality video.
How did you get your hands on that?
Oh, my God, here he comes. This is it.
I don’t know.
Holy crap!
Aah! It’s eating his face!
Sheldon, we’re really sorry.
And what does forty-three mean?
Yeah, well, I know how to make your egg salad now.
Sheldon: It’s a hypothetical containment field for a Frisbee-sized wormhole that could serve as a portal to a parallel universe.
It’s a Frisbee-sized wormhole, Leonard. You can block it with a Frisbee. Calm down.
I expect you to wipe the pudding off your chin. Gentlemen.
Oh, hello.
No, thank you.
I’m quite sure. Good day.
Where are you going?
I just told you.
To be honest, I didn’t know you were here.
You think you don’t care?
Oh, I don’t know. I mean, statistically speaking, I’m sure you have something to worry about.

Well, if we assume your looks are average, yeah, right off the bat, fifty percent of men on Earth are more attractive than you. That’s one point five billion handsome lads standing by, waiting to rain on your parade.
Not height, vision, athleticism, or ability to digest dairy products.
You were just spying on your girlfriend through a peephole.

I’m not saying you don’t have attractive qualities. Your choice of friends is impeccable, you’re a good sleeper, and last but not least, you buy the grapes I like. You’re a real catch compared to some snoring guy with a fridge full of lousy grapes.
Well, unless of course he’s a skilled hypnotist.
While unlikely, it’s still a statistical possibility. She might be performing sexual acts with him and not even know it.
Am I? The mind’s a mysterious thing, Leonard. He could be having the time of his life while she thinks she’s a chicken pecking for corn.
I thought you left a long time ago.
The first forty-three parallel universes I’ve checked proved to be empty. I see no reason to suspect universe number forty-four will be any different. (Puts his head in the wormhole)

Sorry? You may not realize it, but I have difficulty navigating certain aspects of daily life. You know, understanding sarcasm, feigning interest in others, not talking about trains as much as I want to. It’s exhausting. Which is why, for twenty minutes a day, I like to go down to that room, turn my mind off and do what I need to do to recharge.
You don’t need to know, you don’t deserve to know, and you will never know.
One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight… Drat. I’m never going to get to forty-three again. One, two, three, four… Rats.
Howard: Oh, you silly doodlebug.
Do you expect me to build this?
Have you guys ever noticed that Sheldon always disappears every day at two forty-five?

I’m looking at his public calendar. Two forty-five to three-oh-five, nothing. Yesterday, two forty-five to three-oh-five, nothing, last week, nothing, last month, nothing. He never has anything booked during that time.
We should figure out where he goes.
Colonel Koothrapali in the kitchen with the olive spread.
Two forty-four, Right on schedule. Hey, Sheldon.
Raj and I are heading over to the genetics lab to pet the glow-in-the-dark bunny. Want to come with us?
Well, where are you going?
No, you didn’t.
Should we follow him?
Hey, Alex, do you know where your boss just went?
Don’t you know his schedule?
Come on.
This is where he goes? What’s in there?
What could he be doing in there every day for twenty minutes?
Not yet. What are you doing?
Can’t you face the other way and listen?
What the hell is he up to?
Why would he chain up Stephen Hawking?
I think we’re more like ninjas.
Fine, I’ll be a ninja, you be a cat burglar.
Thank you.
It’s locked.
Yes, I’m sure. Now, you stand guard, I’m going to…
Just keep an eye out. I’ll have this open in a minute.
When I was starting to do magic in junior high, I thought I could be an escape artist like Harry Houdini.
Pretty good. I managed to escape friends, popularity, and every party thrown in a twelve mile radius. There. Ready?
What?
Yeah, so?
Don’t worry, I’m one step ahead of him.
Are we good?
I don’t know. The solution to an equation?
What kind of secret does Sheldon have to encrypt?
It’s paprika.
Forty-three. What is forty-three? Besides my mom’s neck size.
That stuff’s radioactive.
Ah, it took him two years to put together that Lego Death Star, I’m not worried.
Why would you know that?
That’s forty-two, dumb-ass.
We should stop. I’m exhausted.
Not me.
Sounds good.
I have to know!
Okay, picture’s up. Looks like the camera’s working.
It better be. It’s the spare camera for the Mars rover.
Million dollar camera, ten dollar lock.
What the hell is that thing?
Wormhole generator test? (On screen a wormhole appears)
Oh, my God!
Yeah, really sorry.
But what are you doing in there?
Leonard: You know, a lot of scientists believe that making contact with other life-forms would probably not end well for us.
Really?
Actually, no, he goes to the bathroom at eight a.m. with optional follow-ups at one forty-five and seven ten high-fibre Fridays.
Oh, that’s just the tip of the sadness iceberg.
Right, the case of who murdered three Saturday nights of my life?
Well, I spent most of the afternoon growing isotopically pure crystals for neutrino detection.
Yeah, it was.
Who you talking to?
Oh, great. We’re still dating, right?
I’m sorry, what was that? I had a little stroke after oral.
Oh, good, an English accent, the sexiest accent you can have.
Did you tell him you have a boyfriend?
Well, maybe you should tell him.
Say, can’t talk right now, hanging with my boyfriend. England sucks, you suck, USA number one.
Yes. Thank you.
What did he say?
What?
I hate this guy.
Come on, trust me, he’s hitting on you.
Really? Here?
That’d be great. Thank you.
If you’re wondering why I’ve been staring through the peephole, I’m trying to get a look at this guy who’s coming over to Penny’s.
It’s not a big deal. He’s just in her history class. They’re working on a project together. I don’t even know why I care. You know what, I don’t care.
This is silly. I have nothing to worry about.
What do you mean?
Well, yeah, but this isn’t just about looks. I’m, I’m way above average in a lot of other things.
I’m talking about important things like emotional maturity.
I liked it better when you thought I wasn’t here.
None of this matters. I trust that Penny cares about me, and nothing’s gonna happen with this guy.
What?
Now you’re just being ridiculous.
I’ll be right back.
You, uh, moving into the apartment on the fifth floor?
Oh, cool. That cute blonde on four?
I, well, I see her around. I like to keep my distance because her boyfriend is a pretty scary dude.
Yeah. He’s ganged up.
That’s the name of his gang. The Scientists. They are crazy.
No problem, brother. Stay frosty. (Cole leaves. Leonard spots Penny watching.) We’re still dating, right?
Hey, Alex, and call me Leonard. Dr. Hofstadter is my father. And my mother. And my sister. And our cat. Although, I’m pretty sure Dr. Boots Hofstadter’s degree was honorary.
Sure.
Hey, Alex, let me ask you something. My girlfriend knows this guy at school. He’s got an English accent.
Yeah, you all do. Anyway, I feel like he’s hitting on her. She says he’s just being nice and that I should trust her.
Right. Because girls are always like, ooh, that guy owns two Star Trek uniforms and gets a lot of ear infections. I got to get me some of that.
Trust me, it doesn’t.
Really?
Hope-hope no girls rip my clothes off on the way.
Hi.
Come on, I’m sorry.
I do, of course I do.
Really?
Oh. You know, I’m really starting to not like this guy.

I don’t know. It-it-it’s hard sometimes. Everywhere you go, guys hit on you, even if I’m standing right there. And they’re all taller than me. Why is everyone taller than me? You know what, this is all in my head. It’s my problem, not yours.
You know that’s the first time you ever said that you love me.
We’re just supposed to pretend it’s not a big deal?
You’re right, you should go.
Penny: So, how was work today?
That sounds like fun.
Oh, good, I guessed right.
Oh, just this guy I met at school.
Relax. He’s just a friend. We’re doing an oral report together. He’s really nice.
Would you stop? Look, he just moved here from London, okay? He doesn’t really know anybody.
No. That’s not true. There’s French, there’s Italian. No, you’re right, it’s the best.
It didn’t come up.
What am I supposed to say?
Fine. Hanging with my boyfriend. Talk to you later. Happy?
Mm-hmm. Hmm.
Nothing.
Did your boyfriend make you type that?
Don’t be like that.
No, he’s not. We’re just friends. Look, is this gonna be a problem? Because he’s supposed to come over tomorrow to work.
If it makes you uncomfortable, I’ll switch partners, even though the thing’s due next week and everyone already has a partner and I’ll probably end up failing the class.
Hey, shouldn’t you be out with your gang, spray painting equations on the side of buildings?
I just can’t believe you don’t trust me.
Then why did you embarrass me in front of my friend, who, by the way, knew exactly who you were?
Your picture’s on my refrigerator.
What is your problem? Do you use up all your thinking at work and then have none left over for when you get home?
Leonard, why do you always do this? Listen to me, you’re the one I’m with. You know I love you, so will you please relax because you’re driving me crazy.
Yeah.
That’s exactly what we’re gonna do because you’re about to make me cry, and we both know if I start crying, you’re gonna start crying.
Alex: All I know is corduroy makes too much noise and I have to go find quieter pants.
It’s probably harmless. You know how it is. I’m sure you get hit on all the time.
I don’t know, I bet it happens more than you realize.
You sure? You’re cute, you’re funny. Maybe you’re getting hit on, and you don’t even know it.
Penny (off): Thanks, Cole. See you at school.
Cole: No, I was just visiting a friend.
She told me he’s a scientist.
Leonard (laughs): Okay, I got to get back to work. Thanks for listening.
Leonard (crying): She loves me. (Receives text) Hey, it’s Alex. Nice having coffee with you. If you want to talk more, I’m always available. Smiley face, smiley face. What a friendly girl.
Sheldon (on screen): This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Experimental log. Wormhole generator test forty-four.
Sheldon (throwing alien onto the laptop): I found your webcam and replaced the video feed. You two should be ashamed of yourselves.

Boy, what I wouldn’t give to get her out of those pants and into something a little more stylish.

I liked it better when you thought I wasn’t here.

Am I? The mind’s a mysterious thing, Leonard. He could be having the time of his life while she thinks she’s a chicken pecking for corn.
Look at us, sneaking around in the middle of the night like a couple of cat burglars.
I think we’re more like ninjas.
I don’t want to be a ninja, I want to be a cat burglar.
Fine, I’ll be a ninja, you be a cat burglar.
No, we both have to be the same thing. Okay, we’re ninjas.
But next time, we’ll be cat burglars.
Yes, I’m sure. Now, you stand guard, I’m going to…
Just keep an eye out. I’ll have this open in a minute.
When did you learn how to pick locks?
When I was starting to do magic in junior high, I thought I could be an escape artist like Harry Houdini.
Pretty good. I managed to escape friends, popularity, and every party thrown in a twelve mile radius. There. Ready?
Sheldon is a very smart man, and he obviously wants to keep this a secret.
Don’t worry, I’m one step ahead of him.
Great, what’s your pl… (Howard pushes him inside)
Yeah. Huh. Forty-three? What the hell does that mean?
I don’t know. The solution to an equation?
Maybe. It’s a prime number. Encryption systems are built on prime numbers.
What kind of secret does Sheldon have to encrypt?
He’s always been very cagey about what he puts in his egg salad to make it so tasty.
Really? Well, oh, okay, one mystery solved.
Thanks, Cole. See you at school.
I thought you left a long time ago.
Leonard (rushing to catch up with Cole)
You, uh, moving into the apartment on the fifth floor?
No, I was just visiting a friend.
Oh, cool. That cute blonde on four?
I, well, I see her around. I like to keep my distance because her boyfriend is a pretty scary dude.
She told me he’s a scientist.
That’s the name of his gang. The Scientists. They are crazy.
No problem, brother. Stay frosty. (Cole leaves. Leonard spots Penny watching.) We’re still dating, right?
Hey, Alex, and call me Leonard. Dr. Hofstadter is my father. And my mother. And my sister. And our cat. Although, I’m pretty sure Dr. Boots Hofstadter’s degree was honorary.
Hey, Alex, let me ask you something. My girlfriend knows this guy at school. He’s got an English accent.
Yeah, you all do. Anyway, I feel like he’s hitting on her. She says he’s just being nice and that I should trust her.
It’s probably harmless. You know how it is. I’m sure you get hit on all the time.
Right. Because girls are always like, ooh, that guy owns two Star Trek uniforms and gets a lot of ear infections. I got to get me some of that.
I don’t know, I bet it happens more than you realize.
You sure? You’re cute, you’re funny. Maybe you’re getting hit on, and you don’t even know it.
Okay, I got to get back to work. Thanks for listening.
Hope-hope no girls rip my clothes off on the way.
Come on, we’re smart guys. We can figure this out.
Forty-three. What is forty-three? Besides my mom’s neck size.
It’s the atomic number for technetium.
Do you think he’s building a bomb?
Ah, it took him two years to put together that Lego Death Star, I’m not worried.
Ooh, this could be something. forty-three is the number of calories in half a cup of fat-free yoghurt.
I’m sorry. We can’t all eat whatever we want and still stay thin. Wait, in the Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, isn’t forty-three the answer to the question of life, the universe,and everything?
Yeah, me, too. We’ve got more important things to do. Who cares what stupid forty-three means?
Let’s go home. You want to get something to eat?
Hey, shouldn’t you be out with your gang, spray painting equations on the side of buildings?
I just can’t believe you don’t trust me.
I do, of course I do.
Then why did you embarrass me in front of my friend, who, by the way, knew exactly who you were?
Oh. You know, I’m really starting to not like this guy.
What is your problem? Do you use up all your thinking at work and then have none left over for when you get home?

I don’t know. It-it-it’s hard sometimes. Everywhere you go, guys hit on you, even if I’m standing right there. And they’re all taller than me. Why is everyone taller than me? You know what, this is all in my head. It’s my problem, not yours.
Leonard, why do you always do this? Listen to me, you’re the one I’m with. You know I love you, so will you please relax because you’re driving me crazy.
You know that’s the first time you ever said that you love me.
We’re just supposed to pretend it’s not a big deal?
That’s exactly what we’re gonna do because you’re about to make me cry, and we both know if I start crying, you’re gonna start crying.
She loves me. (Receives text) Hey, it’s Alex. Nice having coffee with you. If you want to talk more, I’m always available. Smiley face, smiley face. What a friendly girl.
Okay, picture’s up. Looks like the camera’s working.
It better be. It’s the spare camera for the Mars rover.
How did you get your hands on that?
Million dollar camera, ten dollar lock.
Oh, my God, here he comes. This is it.
What the hell is that thing?
This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Experimental log. Wormhole generator test forty-four.
Wormhole generator test? (On screen a wormhole appears)
The first forty-three parallel universes I’ve checked proved to be empty. I see no reason to suspect universe number forty-four will be any different. (Puts his head in the wormhole)
Sheldon (with an alien creature stuck to his face)
I found your webcam and replaced the video feed. You two should be ashamed of yourselves.

Sorry? You may not realize it, but I have difficulty navigating certain aspects of daily life. You know, understanding sarcasm, feigning interest in others, not talking about trains as much as I want to. It’s exhausting. Which is why, for twenty minutes a day, I like to go down to that room, turn my mind off and do what I need to do to recharge.
But what are you doing in there?
You don’t need to know, you don’t deserve to know, and you will never know.
Yeah, well, I know how to make your egg salad now.
The room in the basement. Sheldon enters, takes out a box, takes a beanbag from the box, then starts playing keepie-uppie,
One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight… Drat. I’m never going to get to forty-three again. One, two, three, four… Rats.
